content: The ***Singapore Herald*** was a [tabloid](/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)) newspaper in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) whose publishing license was suspended by the [Singapore government](/wiki/Singapore_government) on 28 May 1971. The government had accused the paper of being involved in "[black operations](/wiki/Black_operations)", of being funded by questionable foreign sources, of working up agitation against national policies and institutions and of "taking on the government". ## History In 1974, the government strengthened press control through the [Newspaper and Printing Presses Act](/wiki/Newspaper_and_Printing_Presses_Act). Its editors included [M.G.G. Pillai](/wiki/M.G.G._Pillai) and Adele Koh, who were both Malaysians. Koh later moved to Australia, becoming the second wife of [Don Dunstan](/wiki/Don_Dunstan), the former [Premier of South Australia](/wiki/Premier_of_South_Australia). - [Censorship in Singapore](/wiki/Censorship_in_Singapore) - [List of newspapers in Singapore](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Singapore) ## Sources - [Seow, Francis T.](/wiki/Francis_Seow) 1998. *The Media Enthralled: Singapore Revisited*.
